Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on December 7, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service
plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and every
15 calendar days thereafter, an institution shall

complete a written service plan. The service plan shall
include all of the following:
• (a) The reason for continued care.
• (b) Evaluation of service needs.
• (c) Ongoing service needs.
• (d) How service needs will be met.
• (e) Unmet service needs and the reasons
those needs are unmet.
One of two youth files reviewed that required a 30-day updated service plan did
not have it completed.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental follow
up that is needed, have been reviewed with the
resident and with the parent and with the responsible
case manager.
Four of four closed files reviewed did not have a statement that the youths needs
had been reviewed with youth, parent, or case manager.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
Five of fifteen new employee files reviewed did not have the references
completed as required by the rule.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Facility is allowed to use the Psychiatric Consent form from youth’s prior
placement as long as it has the youth’s information, prescribing physician, and
current medication information.
• An incident report must be completed for each restraint hold.
• Incident reports must be entered into MiSACWIS within 24 hours and approved
within 72 hours.
• Notification must be sent to DCWL consultant whenever a youth’s behaviors
result in contact with law enforcement.
• DCWL approved a youth to be provided temporary one on one programing in
the classroom area away from the population of the Shelter Program due to
the youth’s emotional unpredictability and attempting to kill the other youth in
the shelter. The Qualified Fire Inspector (QFI ) has approved the classroom as
an isolation bedroom, as it has two exits and there would be one on one
staffing. There will be a privacy screened sleeping area in the classroom. The
classroom is not locked and there is a bathroom right outside the door. Youth
will shower when the other youth are at the dining hall area. As the QFI
approved the classroom based on the bedroom requirements, this does not
require a variance. But this is different than normal, as the classroom was not
approved for that use upon original licensure.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• A review of the audit process was conducted with the case manager. This
review included the rules and a review of the audit workbook tool.
• Discussion was had with Chief Administrator regarding the seclusion
variance’s that are being approved for the detention population and the
process of requesting a variance was reviewed.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were three substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period. The Chief Administrator placed one of the staff on leave until the
conclusion of the investigation at which time the staff’s employement was
terminated; one of the staff was placed on a safety plan and resigned during the
investigation; and one of the staff was placed on a safety plan throughout the
investigation and resigned once the investigation was concluded. A meeting was
held with the facility leadership on November 28, 2023, at which time staffing was
discussed. Concerns about the lack of adequate staffing and the decisions the
staff are making after being trained was addressed with the leadership. The Chief
Adminstrator reporeted they are enhancing the training, creating expecations for

leadership to be a presence on the units on all shifts, and having leadership take
on more of mentoring responsibility for the new staff at this time.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period. The CAP’s were approved on October 31, 2023 and
November 28, 2023. The facility’s corrective action plan compliance is monitored
quarterly, and first review will be completed in December 2023.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Financial Overview:
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget
and the agency’s financial audit.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator completed an assessment of the program dated
December 1, 2023. The assessment addresses the staffing shortage that the
facility struggles to overcome, and the extensive mental health needs of the youth
placed outside the scope of the program. The Chief Administrator continues to
assess the areas of ongoing need and growth within the teams. The assessment
reports a trend for staff not performing to the standards the facility expects which is
being addressed by continuing to grow and develop staff through staff training.
The assessment also indicated a need to improve documentation for accuracy,
timeliness, and overall compliance. The Chief Administrator’s corrective action
plans have begun to be implemented and they report compliance at this time.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Youth from both the detention and shelter programs were interviewed. Three of
four of the youth report feeling safe at the facility, one reported feeling unsafe due
to the behaviors of the other youth in the program. The youth that reported feeling
unsafe reported the staff do “all they can” to stop the unsafe youth however she
still feels unsafe around specific peers. All four youth reported having all their
needs met by the staff, including crisis counseling as needed. None of the youth
reported concerns with the way in which the staff treat them or with the program.
Staff from different area of the program were interviewed. All staff report having
the training required by the rules. The staff all reported they felt well prepared
through the training to work with the youth. The staff said they feel supported by
direct supervisors and administration. There were no concerns noted by any of the
staff members interviewed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on December 7,
2023. There were no issues or safety concerns noted. The youth all have

appropriate bedrooms and bathroom with adequate supplies. The medications are
double locked. The signage required by the rules is posted in the appropriate
areas at the facility. The kitchen was clean and menus for the youth were posted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
